column6: Change log is present and contains the required information (date, version, sections changed, summary of changes, reason, authors).
column9: Change log is present but inconsistent.

column6: Problem statement clearly communicates the project’s WHY (the underlying need/pain, who is impacted, and why it matters) without drifting into solution design; it is complete and well-structured, covering the issue being addressed, its significance, and the context.
column9: Problem statement exists but the WHY is vague, mixed with implementation details, or incomplete in some areas.
column12: Problem statement is missing or unclear.

column6: Primary and secondary users are clearly identified and current.
column9: Users are listed but are vague or incomplete.

column6: Context of use is clear and current (where/when/how the system will be used).
column9: Context is mentioned but lacks detail.

column6: Includes 2+ measurable success criteria that match the project and are clearly measurable.
column9: Includes at least one success criterion; measurability may be weak.
column12: Success criteria are missing or purely subjective.

column6: Includes at least one explicit non-goal that clarifies boundaries.

column1: Requirements: atomic, testable, unambiguous, with unique IDs
column6: Requirements are atomic, testable, unambiguous, and consistently labeled with unique IDs.
column9: Mostly atomic/testable with IDs; some compound ("A and B"), ambiguous, or multi-scenario items remain.
column12: Many vague/compound requirements and/or missing IDs.

column6: Prioritization is clear and consistent across requirements; rationale for priorities is plausible.
column9: Priorities exist but are inconsistently applied or lightly justified.

column1: Requirements: acceptance criteria for high-priority items
column6: High-priority items include clear acceptance criteria (e.g., Given/When/Then) that are testable.
column9: Some ACs exist but coverage or quality is uneven.

column6: Non-functional requirements/constraints are present and written in a testable way where possible.
Dependencies are noted; implementation status is current; links to PRs/issues/artifacts are included where relevant.
column9: Some dependencies/status/links/artifacts are present but incomplete.
column12: Little or no traceability or status.

column1: Product and stakeholder risks: identification quality
column6: Key product/stakeholder risks are identified and are project-specific.
column12: Risk list is superficial or missing important risks.

column1: Product and stakeholder risks: impact and likelihood
column6: Risks include clear impact and likelihood assessments.

column1: Product and stakeholder risks: mitigation and mapping
column6: Mitigations are concrete; mapping to affected requirements is clear and accurate.
column9: Basic mitigations exist; mapping may be incomplete.

column6: Concise, well-structured, polished; uses clear headings and bullets; stays close to the expected core length (~2–4 pages) while still being complete; images/media enhance readability.
column9: Mostly clear with some structure; minor readability issues or slightly off-target length.

column6: Professional tone; claims are precise and easy to follow; requirements and acceptance criteria use consistent formatting and are written in verifiable language.
column9: Generally clear; occasional ambiguity, inconsistent formatting, or awkward wording.
column12: Unclear or unprofessional tone; inconsistent or confusing requirement/AC wording.

column6: Images/media are legible and include alt text and short captions; links are descriptive; private links include lightweight screenshots/snippets so graders can evaluate.
column9: Some accessibility practices are used; minor gaps (e.g., missing some alt text/captions or vague link text).
column12: Missing alt text/captions or inaccessible formatting; evidence not evaluable due to inaccessible/private links.
